questions.text: The given device can administer a oxygen concentration of upto
questions.solution:
• A non-rebreathing mask is designed to deliver high concentrations of oxygen.
  • It includes three unidirectional valves:
    • Two valves allow exhaled gases to escape and prevent room air from entering.
    • One valve between the mask and the reservoir bag prevents exhaled gases from re-entering the bag.
  • To ensure optimal oxygen delivery, the bag must remain inflated throughout the ventilatory cycle.
  • The typical FIO2 (fraction of inspired oxygen) provided by this device ranges from 0.80 to 0.90.
  • Fresh gas flow is generally set at 15 L/min, allowing for the delivery of oxygen concentrations approaching 1.0(100%) if no room air is entrained.

Why Not Others:

  • A) 100%: While it can approach this value, it cannot consistently deliver pure oxygen due to potential room air entrainment.
  • B) 40%: This concentration is lower than what the non-rebreathing mask can provide.
  • C) 21%: This is the oxygen concentration of ambient air, which does not apply to the non-rebreathing mask.

Key Takeaways:

  • The non-rebreathing mask is effective for delivering high oxygen concentrations (up to 80% or more) due to its design, which minimizes room air entrainment.
  • It is crucial for the bag to be maintained in an inflated state to maximize oxygen delivery and minimize re-breathing of carbon dioxide.

questions.text: While administering oxygen to the patient, the following devices play a role of variable flow administers of Oxygen. These work on the principle of
questions.solution:
• Venturi masks utilize the Venturi effect, which relies on the Bernoulli principle.
  • Key Concepts:
    • The rapid flow of gas (like oxygen) through a restricted orifice creates a low-pressure area down stream
    • This low pressure allows room air to be entrained, mixing with the oxygen to achieve a desired oxygen concentration.
    • By adjusting the size of the gas orifice or entrainment ports, the FIO2(fraction of inspired oxygen) can be varied predictably.
    • Venturi devices provide reliable FIO2 values ranging from 0.24 to 0.50, independent of the patient's breathing pattern.

Why Not Others:

  • B) Bernoulli's: Although the Venturi effect is based on the Bernoulli principle, the question specifically asks for the principle governing variable flow devices, which is primarily the Venturi effect.
  • C) Coanda: This principle relates to fluid dynamics but is not the main principle behind Venturi devices.
  • D) All of the above: While related, only the Venturi principle specifically pertains to variable flow oxygen administration devices.

Key Takeaways:

  • Venturi masks are crucial for delivering controlled oxygen concentrations through the principle of the Venturi effect.
  • Understanding the mechanics of gas flow and pressure dynamics is vital for effective oxygen therapy management.

questions.text: Match the following oxygen delivery devices with their maximum percentage of oxygen delivered
questions.solution:
• Rebreathing mask: Can deliver up to 90% oxygen when the reservoir bag is filled adequately and the mask fits well.
  • Venturi mask: Provides a predetermined concentration of oxygen, typically delivering around 50%, depending on the flow rate and the design of the device.
  • Hudson mask: Generally delivers around 60% oxygen at higher flow rates.
  • Nasal cannula: Usually delivers up to 40% oxygen when set at higher flow rates, often between 1 to 6 L/min.

Key Takeaways:

  • Understanding the delivery capacities of various oxygen devices is essential for appropriate patient management in respiratory care.
  • Each device has specific uses based on the required oxygen concentration for different clinical scenarios.

questions.text: To ensure strict regulation of the inspired oxygen concentration, all of the following devices can be used except, in other words which of the given options provide variable oxygen levels:
questions.solution:
• Variable Performance (Low-Flow Systems):
    • Nasal prongs/cannula: Provide variable oxygen concentration depending on the flow rate and patient's breathing pattern.
    • Hudson mask (simple face mask): Allows for variable oxygen levels, as room air is entrained, depending on the flow rate.
    • Mask with reservoir bag: Can provide higher concentrations but is still considered variable as it relies on the patient's breathing and reservoir bag inflation.
  • Fixed Performance (High-Flow Systems):
    • Venturi mask: Delivers a specific and fixed concentration of oxygen, ensuring precise regulation of inspired oxygen levels by using air entrainment mechanisms. It provides consistent FiO2 regardless of the patient's breathing pattern.

Why Not Others:

  • Hudson masks: These masks do not provide a fixed oxygen concentration as they allow room air to mix with the supplied oxygen, resulting in variable FiO2 levels.
  • Mask with reservoir bag: While it can deliver higher oxygen concentrations, it still varies based on the patient's respiratory effort and how well the bag is maintained.
  • Nasal prongs: Similar to Hudson masks, they entrain room air, which results in variable oxygen delivery depending on the flow rate and patient's breathing pattern.

Key Takeaways:

  • Understanding the difference between variable and fixed performance devices is crucial in oxygen therapy management.
  • For precise oxygen delivery, devices like the Venturi mask are preferred, while devices like Hudson masks and nasal prongs provide variable oxygen concentrations.

questions.text: The end of preoxygenation can be determined by
questions.solution:
• Preoxygenation is the process of replacing nitrogen in the lungs with oxygen, creating an apneic oxygen reservoir.
  • Ideal Conditions: A healthy individual breathing room air (FiO2 = 0.21) can experience significant desaturation (below 90%) after 1-2 minutes of apnea.
  • Oxygen Support: With preoxygenation at 100% O2 via a tight-fitting mask, a patient can maintain oxygenation for approximately 8 minutes of apnea.
  • End-tidal oxygen concentration:
    • 90% or Higher: An EtO2 concentration of 90% or greater indicates maximal preoxygenation.
  • End-tidal nitrogen concentration:
    • 5% Threshold:An EtN2 concentration of 5% signifies maximal preoxygenation.
  • Time-based Assessment:
    • If EtO2 analysis is unavailable, preoxygenation is generally deemed complete after 3 minutes.
  • Breath Count:
    • Alternatively, achieving 8 vital capacity breaths can also indicate adequate preoxygenation.

Why Not Others:

  • Pulse oximetry: While helpful in monitoring oxygen saturation, it does not provide specific data on end-tidal oxygen concentration.
  • Does not need an end point: Preoxygenation requires assessment to ensure efficacy; an endpoint is crucial for adequate oxygenation.
  • End tidal carbon dioxide concentration: This does not indicate oxygen levels; it primarily reflects ventilation status, not the adequacy of preoxygenation.

Key Takeaways:

  • The end of preoxygenation is best assessed through end-tidal oxygen concentration (EtO2).
  • Monitoring oxygen levels is vital to ensure adequate oxygenation before procedures requiring apnea.

questions.text: High flow oxygen therapy uses high inspired flow rates of Oxygen. The flow rate ranges from:
questions.solution:
• High Flow Nasal Oxygen (HFNO):
    • Specialized Equipment: Utilizes specific nasal cannula designed to deliver high flow rates effectively.
    • FiO2 Achieved: Can reach FiO2 levels approaching 100% by providing a continuous flow of oxygen.
  • Flow Rates:
    • Patient Needs: High flow oxygen therapy is tailored to meet or exceed the patient's peak inspiratory flow rates, generally falling between 40-70 L/min.
    • Improved Ventilation: This therapy allows for better ventilation and oxygenation, especially in patients with respiratory distress.
  • Clinical Use:
    • Conditions Treated: Commonly used in acute respiratory failure, pneumonia, and post-extubation support.
    • Comfort and Tolerance: Patients often find HFNO more comfortable than traditional oxygen delivery methods.

Why Not Others:

  • Less than 40 L per minute: This flow rate is insufficient for high flow therapy and does not meet the intended objectives.
  • More than 70 L per minute: While devices can theoretically reach this range, it is not standard practice and may not be clinically beneficial.
  • 70-100 L per minute: This range is rarely employed in clinical settings and may exceed physiological requirements.

Key Takeaways:

  • High flow oxygen therapy typically delivers oxygen at flow rates of 40-70 L/min.
  • It effectively improves patient oxygenation and ventilation, particularly beneficial for patients in respiratory distress.
  • The therapy is associated with increased patient comfort and a lower risk of complications compared to traditional oxygen delivery methods.

Reference: ATOTW 437 - High Flow Oxygen in Anaesthesia and Critical Care (8 December 2020)

questions.text: High flow nasal oxygen help in oxygenation of patients in the intensive care. All of the following patients can benefit from THRIVE except:
questions.solution:
• High Flow Nasal Oxygen (HFNO):
    • Delivery Method: Administered through specialized nasal cannula.
    • Flow Rate: Achieves flow rates up to 70 L/min with FiO2 nearing 100%.
    • Indications: Effective for spontaneously breathing patients with respiratory distress.
  • THRIVE Study:
    • Transnasal Humidified Rapid Insufflation Ventilatory Exchange: Research supports HFNO's use in apnoeic patients and during procedures under anaesthesia.
    • Mechanism: Helps prolong apnoeic oxygenation and improves time to desaturation during intubation attempts.
  • Patient Considerations:
    • Spontaneously Breathing: Patients must be able to breathe on their own and protect their airways for HFNO to be beneficial.
    • Cognitive Status:A Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) < 8/15 indicates severe impairment and inability to protect the airway, making HFNO inappropriate.

Why Not Others:

  • COPD: These patients can benefit from HFNO to alleviate hypoxemia and improve ventilation.
  • ARDS: HFNO is used to enhance oxygenation and reduce work of breathing in ARDS patients.
  • Pneumonia: HFNO helps in oxygenation and alleviating respiratory distress in pneumonia patients.

Key Takeaways:

  • HFNO is effective in spontaneously breathing patients with respiratory distress, particularly in conditions like COPD, ARDS, and pneumonia.
  • It is not suitable for patients with a GCS < 8/15 due to risks associated with airway protection and ventilation needs.

Reference: ATOTW 437 - High Flow Oxygen in Anaesthesia and Critical Care (8 December 2020)

questions.text: Oxygen therapy is indicated in all of the following conditions excepts:
questions.solution:
• Oxygen Therapy: Aims to increase the fraction of inspired oxygen concentration (FiO2) to prevent cellular hypoxia resulting from hypoxemia.
  • Primary Goals: Prevent irreversible damage to vital organs by maintaining adequate oxygen levels in the blood.
  • Main Indications for Oxygen Therapy:
    • Hypoxia: Diminished blood oxygen levels (oxygen saturation <92%).
    • Hypoxemia: Acute and chronic conditions with PaO2 <65 mm Hg (e.g., pneumonia, shock, asthma).
    • Myocardial Ischemia/Infarction: Administered if associated with hypoxemia; caution with high levels in ischemic heart disease/stroke.
    • Low Cardiac Output: Can contribute to metabolic acidosis (HCO3 <18 mmol/L).
    • Chronic Type II Respiratory Failure: Addresses both hypoxia and hypercapnia.
    • Acute Gastrointestinal Blood Loss: Oxygenation support during acute bleeding.
    • Carbon Monoxide Poisoning: Oxygen therapy aids in displacing CO from haemoglobin.

Why Not Others:

  • Hypoxia: Indicated to improve oxygen saturation levels.
  • Hypoxemia: Directly treated to increase oxygen delivery.
  • Metabolic Acidosis: Can benefit from oxygen therapy to support tissue oxygenation despite potential acid-base imbalance.

Key Takeaways:

  • Acid Inhalational Poisoningis not a direct indication for oxygen therapy as it can lead to lung injury and inflammation, potentially making oxygen therapy less effective or even harmful.
  • Oxygen therapy is critical in conditions causing hypoxia and hypoxemia but should be used cautiously in certain situations like metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: Oxygen therapy should be guarded or limited in all the following cases except:
questions.solution:
• Oxygen Therapy Limitation: Careful administration is necessary in certain conditions to prevent complications.
  • Conditions Requiring Caution:
    • Chronic CO2 Retention States:
      • Patients often have low PaO2 and rely on hypoxia for respiratory drive.
      • Oxygen administration can lead to hypoventilation and respiratory failure.
    • Paraquat Poisoning:
      • High levels of oxygen can exacerbate lung injury and increase toxicity.
    • Bleomycin Therapy:
      • Associated with pulmonary toxicity (fibrosis and emphysema) when high oxygen levels are administered.
    • Myocardial Infarction:
      • While oxygen can be beneficial in myocardial infarction, especially if hypoxemia is present, it is not limited as it helps improve oxygen delivery to the heart muscle.

Why Not Others:

  • Chronic CO2 Retention: Risk of hypoventilation.
  • Paraquat Poisoning: Risk of exacerbating lung damage.
  • Bleomycin Therapy: Risk of pulmonary complications from high oxygen.

Key Takeaways:

  • Oxygen therapy is beneficial in myocardial infarction but must be used cautiously in chronic CO2 retention, paraquat poisoning, and bleomycin therapy to prevent adverse effects.

questions.text: Administration of Oxygen in the perioperative settings often require humidification of the supplied Oxygen. The indications of these include:
questions.solution:
• Humidification Importance:
    • Dry oxygen can lead to complications like heat loss, dry mucosa, thick secretions, and airway obstruction. In asthmatic patients, it may cause bronchoconstriction.
  • Indications for Humidification:
    • High Flow Rates:
      • When oxygen flow rates exceed 4 L/min (2 L/min for children <2 years), humidification is necessary to prevent airway irritation and obstruction.
    • Invasive Ventilation:
      • Patients on invasive ventilation require humidified oxygen to maintain mucosal moisture and prevent secretions from becoming thick and obstructive.
    • Retained Secretions:
      • Patients with conditions like bronchiectasis, cystic fibrosis, or chest infections benefit from humidification to help thin secretions, making them easier to expectorate.

Why Not Others:

  • All the options indicate situations where humidification is crucial for patient comfort and safety during oxygen therapy.

Key Takeaways:

  • Humidification is essential in perioperative settings for high flow rates, invasive ventilation, and retained secretions to prevent complications associated with dry oxygen therapy.

questions.text: The oxygen delivery to the cellular level utilization happens and allows aerobic glycolysis in the mitochondria. When there isn't enough oxygen , the metabolism shifts to anaerobic. This shift occurs
questions.solution:
• Pasteur Point:
    • The Pasteur point represents the critical partial pressure of oxygen (PO2) below which aerobic metabolism is impaired, typically estimated to be between 0.15-0.3 kPa (1.4-2.3 mmHg).
  • Oxygen Cascade:
    • The oxygen cascade describes the gradual reduction of PO2 from the atmosphere to the mitochondria:
    • Dry Atmospheric Gas: 21 kPa (160 mmHg)
    • Humidified Tracheal Gas: 19.8 kPa (150 mmHg)
    • Alveolar Gas: 14 kPa (106 mmHg)
    • Arterial Blood: 13.3 kPa (100 mmHg)
    • Capillary Blood: 6-7 kPa (45-55 mmHg)
    • Mitochondria: 1-5 kPa (7.5-40 mmHg)
  • Anaerobic Shift:
    • When the PO2 falls below the Pasteur point, cells can no longer sustain aerobic metabolism and must switch to anaerobic metabolism, leading to lactate production and lower energy yield.

Why Not Others:

  • Above Pasteur Point: Aerobic metabolism is maintained, and there's no shift to anaerobic metabolism.
  • Pasteur Point is Constant: It varies depending on tissue types and metabolic demands.
  • Irrespective of Pasteur Point: The shift is directly linked to falling oxygen levels below the Pasteur point.

Key Takeaways:

  • Anaerobic metabolism occurs below the Pasteur point due to insufficient oxygen for aerobic processes, critically affecting cellular energy production.

questions.text: When the patient complaints of abnormal sensation without an apparent stimulus, it is called as
questions.solution:
• Paresthesia:
    • Refers to abnormal sensations such as tingling, prickling, or a "pins and needles" feeling without any external stimulus.
    • Often caused by nerve irritation, compression, or damage.
  • Radiculopathy:
    • Involves pain, weakness, or numbness that follows the path of a nerve root due to compression or injury, typically associated with radicular pain.
  • Hyperpathia:
    • A condition characterized by an exaggerated response to stimuli, often involving pain that is more intense than expected.
  • Allodynia:
    • Refers to pain from stimuli that do not normally provoke pain, such as light touch.

Why Not Others:

  • A) Radiculopathy: Focuses on nerve root involvement and pain distribution rather than abnormal sensations without stimuli.
  • B) Hyperpathia: Relates to heightened sensitivity and exaggerated pain response, not just abnormal sensations.
  • D) Allodynia: Involves pain triggered by non-painful stimuli, which is different from paresthesia.

Key Takeaways:

  • Paresthesia is specifically defined as abnormal sensations without an apparent cause, distinguishing it from other conditions that involve pain or exaggerated responses.

questions.text: The following are the neurotransmitters with inhibitory effects on nociception
questions.solution:
• Serotonin:
    • Primarily known for its inhibitory effects on nociception.
    • Modulates pain perception, reducing the transmission of pain signals in the central nervous system.
    • Plays a role in descending pain pathways, which help inhibit nociceptive input at the spinal cord level.
    • May influence the emotional aspects of pain, enhancing well-being and potentially altering pain thresholds.

Why Not Others:

  • A) Glutamate:
    • An excitatory neurotransmitter involved in synaptic plasticity and signaling.
    • Increases neuronal excitability and enhances pain signaling in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord.
    • Implicated in conditions like neuropathic pain due to its role in central sensitization.
  • B) Substance P:
    • A neuropeptide associated with the transmission of pain and inflammatory responses.
    • Functions as an excitatory neurotransmitter, particularly in the pathways transmitting pain signals from the periphery to the central nervous system.
    • Plays a significant role in the development of chronic pain conditions.
  • D) Aspartate:
    • An excitatory neurotransmitter similar to glutamate, facilitating synaptic transmission.
    • Contributes to pain signaling, especially in response to injury or inflammation, by promoting excitatory postsynaptic potentials.

Key Takeaways:

  • Serotonin serves as an important inhibitory neurotransmitter in nociception, helping to modulate pain and prevent excessive pain signal transmission.
  • In contrast, glutamate, substance P, and aspartate are key players in promoting pain signals, which can exacerbate pain conditions.

questions.text: The following are the elements of pain except
questions.solution:
• The process of pain involves four key elements:
    • Transduction:
      • Involves the conversion of noxious thermal, chemical, or mechanical stimuli into an action potential.
      • This initial step is crucial for the perception of pain.
    • Transmission:
      • Refers to the conduction of action potentials through the nervous system via first-order, second-order, and third-order neurons.
      • These neurons have cell bodies located in the dorsal root ganglion, dorsal horn, and thalamus, respectively.
    • Modulation:
      • Refers to the alteration of afferent neural transmission along the pain pathway.
      • This can either amplify or dampen the pain experience depending on various factors.
    • Sensitization:
      • While related to pain processing, sensitization itself is not considered a core element of the pain pathway.
      • It refers to neuroplastic changes resulting from tissue injury, leading to peripheral and central sensitization.
      • This can manifest clinically as hyperalgesia(exaggerated response to painful stimuli) and allodynia (painful response to normally non-painful stimuli).
      • These phenomena are consequences of altered pain processing rather than elements of the pain pathway itself.

Why Not Others:

  • A) Transduction:
    • A fundamental process in the initiation of pain signaling.
  • B) Transmission:
    • Essential for the propagation of pain signals through the nervous system.
  • D) Modulation:
    • Critical for influencing the overall perception of pain and its intensity.

Key Takeaways:

  • The primary elements of pain processing include transduction, transmission, and modulation.
  • Sensitization, although important in the context of pain perception, is not a direct element of pain processing but rather a consequence of it.

questions.text: All are true regarding phantom limb pain except?
questions.solution:
• Phantom Limb Pain (PLP):
    • Nearly all patients with amputated limbs experience nonpainful sensations in the absent limb, with around 60% experiencing pain.
    • The onset of phantom limb pain may occur immediately or typically within the first few days after amputation.
    • Over time, approximately 50% of patients may experience a decrease in pain, while others report no change or an increase.
  • Mechanisms of Phantom Limb Pain:
    • Peripheral Mechanisms:
      • Involves factors such as neuromas (nerve growths), increased C-fiber activity (not A delta-fiber), and sodium channel activation.
      • A delta fibers are primarily associated with sharp, acute pain, not specifically linked to phantom pain.
    • Central Mechanisms:
      • Includes abnormal firing of spinal internuncial neurons and changes in the central nervous system due to the development of new synaptic connections in the cerebral cortex.
    • Treatment Approaches:
      • Nonpharmacologic measures include transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation, spinal cord stimulators, and biofeedback.
      • A combination of pharmacologic treatment with physical, psychological, or behavioural interventions is often the most effective strategy for managing phantom limb pain.

Why Not Others:

  • A) Behavioural intervention is probably the most effective approach:
    • Behavioural interventions are indeed effective, often as part of a multimodal treatment strategy.
  • C) Central mechanisms include abnormal firing of spinal internuncial neurons:
    • This is true and is recognized as a contributing factor to phantom limb pain.
  • D) The onset of pain may be immediate but commonly occurs within the first few days following amputation:
    • This statement accurately reflects the common experiences of patients following amputation.

Key Takeaways:

  • Phantom limb pain arises from a combination of peripheral and central mechanisms, with peripheral mechanisms not primarily involving A delta-fiber activity but rather C-fiber activity and neuromas.
  • The onset of pain can be immediate or delayed, with various treatment options available that emphasize a multimodal approach for effective management.
